class_notes:
This course provides a thematic survey of the history of political philosophy, with a focus on the idea of the 'social contract' found in a number of thinkers from Antiquity to Modernity and 20thCentury. In the first part of the course, we will study various versions of the social contract theory and the cluster of concepts around this theory: freedom (liberty/slavery); justice (race, sex/gender, 
class/caste, labor, land, property, rights), and revolution. (reform, liberation, abolition). In the second part of the course, we will study the American and Haitian Revolutions in connection with and a focus on contemporary racial and social justice movements.
course_description: Surveys key texts in political philosophy, including ancient, early modern, 19th and 20th century sources. Key issues include the nature of the just state and the rights and responsibilities of citizens.
prerequisites: Any 100 level PHIL or PHIL_OX or equivalent transfer credit course as prerequisite.
